question: A 3-month-old girl is brought to a pediatrician by her parents. She has central cyanosis without signs of respiratory distress or signs of heart failure. An echocardiogram reveals severe pulmonary outflow obstruction, right ventricular hypertrophy, a ventricular septal defect, and an overriding of the aorta. An elective primary surgical repair is planned at 4 months of age. Which of the following statements is true about this girl’s condition?

options.A: The tricuspid valve is the most common valve affected by bacterial endocarditis in uncorrected tetralogy of Fallot.
options.B: Normal hemoglobin in patients with tetralogy of Fallot does not rule out iron deficiency anemia.
options.C: Cerebral arterial thrombosis is more common than cerebral venous thrombosis.
options.D: Refractory heart failure is a common complication of tetralogy of Fallot.

The 3-month-old girl has central cyanosis, severe pulmonary outflow obstruction, right ventricular hypertrophy, a ventricular septal defect, and an overriding aorta. These findings are consistent with Tetralogy of Fallot, a common cyanotic congenital heart defect. According to Document [3] (Title: Pediatrics_Nelson), Tetralogy of Fallot is due to abnormal septation of the truncus arteriosus into the aorta and pulmonary artery that occurs early in gestation, resulting in a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. The presence of these abnormalities indicates that the girl's condition is Tetralogy of Fallot. Now, let's evaluate the answer choices in relation to Tetralogy of Fallot.

A. The tricuspid valve is not the most common valve affected by bacterial endocarditis in uncorrected Tetralogy of Fallot. According to Document [2] (Title: Pediatrics_Nelson), the most common cyanotic congenital heart lesion in the newborn is Transposition of the Great Vessels, and it is not directly related to Tetralogy of Fallot. However, Document [30] (Title: InternalMed_Harrison) mentions that tricuspid regurgitation may become progressively regurgitant in the postoperative patient with Tetralogy of Fallot if RV outflow tract obstruction was not relieved adequately at initial surgery. So, this statement is not entirely accurate.

B. Normal hemoglobin in patients with Tetralogy of Fallot does not rule out iron deficiency anemia. Document [11] (Title: Pediatrics_Nelson) states that infants with Tetralogy of Fallot may present with signs of anemia, including poor appetite, fatigue, and jaundice. Therefore, this statement is true.

C. Cerebral arterial thrombosis is more common than cerebral venous thrombosis in patients with Tetralogy of Fallot. However, there is no specific information in the provided documents to support this statement. Document [26] (Title: Surgery_Schwartz) mentions that cerebral arterial thrombosis is a potential complication of Tetralogy of Fallot, but it does not compare the frequency of cerebral arterial and venous thrombosis.

D. Refractory heart failure is not a common complication of Tetralogy of Fallot. According to Document [2] (Title: Pediatrics_Nelson), most patients with Tetralogy of Fallot can be asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms, and heart failure is not a common complication. However, Document [30] (Title: InternalMed_Harrison) states that inadequate relief of an obstructive lesion, a residual regurgitant lesion, or a residual shunt can cause or hasten the onset of clinical signs and symptoms of myocardial dysfunction. There is marked right ventricular hypertrophy, since that chamber functions as the systemic ventricle; the left ventricle is hypoplastic, since it pumps only to the low-resistance pulmonary circulation. Some newborns with transposition of the great arteries have a patent foramen ovale or PDA that allows oxygenated blood to reach the aorta, but these tend to close; such infants typically require emergent surgical intervention within the first few days of life. The dominant manifestation is cyanosis, with the prognosis depending on the magnitude of shunting, the degree of tissue hypoxia, and the ability of the right ventricle to maintain systemic pressures. Without surgery (even with stable shunting), most patients with uncorrected transposition of the great arteries die within the first months of life. However, improved surgical techniques now permit definitive repair, and such patients often survive into adulthood.

snippets.title: Anatomy_Gray
snippets.content: The tetralogy of Fallot, the most common cyanotic congenital heart disorder diagnosed soon after birth, classically consists of four abnormalities: pulmonary stenosis, VSD, overriding aorta (originating to a varying degree from the right ventricle), and right ventricular hypertrophy. The underdevelopment of the right ventricle and pulmonary stenosis reduce blood flow to the lungs, leading to reduced volume of oxygenated blood returning to the heart. The defect in the interventricular septum causes mixing of oxygenated and nonoxygenated blood. The mixed blood is then delivered by the aorta to the major organs, resulting in poor oxygenation and cyanosis. Infants can present with cyanosis at birth or develop episodes of cyanosis while feeding or crying (tet spells). Most affected infants require surgical intervention. The advent of cardiopulmonary bypass was crucial in delivering highly satisfactory surgical results.

snippets.title: Pediatrics_Nelson
snippets.content: Tetralogy of Fallot is the most common cyanotic congenital heart defect, representing about 10% of all congenital heart defects (Fig. 144-1). There are four structural defects: ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. Tetralogy of Fallot is due to abnormal septation of the truncus arteriosus into the aorta and pulmonary artery that occurs early in gestation (3to 4 weeks). The VSD is large and the pulmonary stenosis is most commonly subvalvular or infundibular. It may also be valvular, supravalvular, or, frequently, a combination of levels of obstruction.

The initial presentation of a child afflicted with TOF depends on the degree of RVOT obstruction. Children with cyanosis at birth usually have severe pulmonary annular hypoplasia with concomitant hypoplasia of the peripheral pulmonary arteries. Most children, however, present with mild cyanosis at birth, which then pro-gresses as the right ventricular hypertrophy further compromises the RVOT. Cyanosis usually becomes significant within the first 6 to 12 months of life, and the child may develop characteristic “tet” spells, which are periods of extreme hypoxemia. These spells are characterized by decreased pulmonary blood flow and an increase in systemic blood flow. Pulmonary stenosis results from the failure of the development, in early gestation, of the three leaflets of the valve, insufficient resorption of infundibular tissue, or insufficient canalization of the peripheral pulmonary arteries. Symptoms depend on the degree of obstruction present. Mild pulmonary stenosis is asymptomatic. Moderate to severe stenosis results in exertional dyspnea and easy fatigability. In many patients with surgically modified CHD, inadequate relief of an obstructive lesion, a residual regurgitant lesion, or a residual shunt will cause or hasten the onset of clinical signs and symptoms of myocardial dysfunction. snippets.title: Pediatrics_Nelson
snippets.content: Clinical manifestations of a PDA usually become apparent on day 2 to 4 of life. Because the left-to-right shunt directs flow to a low-pressure circulation from one of high pressure, the pulse pressure widens; a previously inactive precordium shows an extremely active precordial impulse, and peripheral pulses become easily palpable and bounding. The murmur of a PDA may be continuous in systole and diastole, but usually only the systolic component is auscultated. Heart failure and pulmonary edema result in rales and hepatomegaly. A chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly and pulmonary edema; a two-dimensional echocardiogram shows ductal patency; and Doppler studies show markedly increased left-to-right flow through the ductus.
